Dear Mr. McKeage:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Claudia Triestram at 616-552-3662.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description
(4) Only the least restrictive intervention necessary to prevent
immediate harm to the youth or others may be used and must
follow an individualized set of graduated interventions that avoid
the use of restraints.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 7/25/23, staff performed an unwarranted restraint.
Investigation On 8/2/23, I interviewed Complainant, also DCWL Area Manager,
via phone regarding the allegation. She said a review of
MISACWIS incident report #159460207 dated 7/25/23 indicated
staff at the facility physically restrained Youth T for taking off her
shirt and pulling a fire alarm, and these reasons for physical
restraint were unjustified.
I notified Youth T’s Juvenile Justice Worker of the investigation
assignment.
I contacted Chief Administrator via phone requesting staff
schedules to arrange interviews.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing rule violations.
I arrived unannounced at the facility on 8/3/23 and reviewed video
of the incident with assistance from Chief Administrator and
Operations Manager.
VIDEO of Pod 3 on 7/25/23 (no audio)
3:02 – Youth T is sitting on a chair in the corner of the pod
refusing to comply with staff directives. Supervisor, Staff 1, 2, 3
and 4 are standing talking with her. The other youths are inside of
their rooms.
3:02 – 3:09:46 – Staff 2, 3 and 4 continue talking with Youth T
while Supervisor and Staff 1 search her room and remove trash.
Supervisor and Staff 1 return to verbally intervene.
3:09:47 – Youth T takes both arms out of her shirt leaving it
hanging on her neck.
3:11:12 – Youth T takes the shirt off her neck, and it drops to the
floor. She is left wearing a sports bra and pants. Staff continue
talking with her.
2

3:11:53 – Youth T pulls a fire alarm nearby. *Note: When the fire
alarm goes off, all staff and youth in the building hear the alarm
and staff begin gathering youths to safety until Staff 1 radioed that
it was a false alarm.
3:12 – Supervisor initiates a standing Primary Restraint Technique
(PRT) single person escort method. Youth T drops to her knees.
3:12 – 3:17:49 - Supervisor pulls Youth T up to the wall and
initiates a PRT Standing Wall restraint. Supervisor maintains the
single person restraint.
3:17:50 - Youth T walks to her room escorted by Supervisor.
Bay Pines Center utilizes the Handle with Care physical
management training model. Supervisor is a Handle with Care
trainer. There are no disciplinary write-ups in Supervisor’s
employee file.
I reviewed the Handle with Care restraint techniques training
manual. PRT as a Standing Wall restraint is an approved
technique that instructs staff “For an in-facing wall restraint,
always back yourself to the wall and turn the client to face the wall
on the tightest possible axis to avoid impact.”
I interviewed Youth T, age 18. MISACWIS indicates she is a
delinquent state ward who was in the Macomb County Detention
Center from 7/26/21 – 4/11/23 and transferred to Bay Pines for
residential sex offender and victimization treatment on 4/11/23.
On the date of the incident Youth T said Staff 1 asked her to go to
her room and she refused. “I don’t know why I pulled the fire
alarm. Supervisor restrained me with my arms back and up
against the wall. He didn’t hurt me. He was trying to help.” I
asked Youth T about the other staff. She offered “Staff 1 is a
good staff. She didn’t do nothing wrong. She just gets
disappointed when she knows we can do better.” I asked Youth T
why she takes off her clothes. She answered, “It’s related to my
trauma.”
I interviewed Supervisor. He is a Handle with Care trainer, has
worked at the facility for 13 years and been a supervisor for the
last five. On 7/25/23 Supervisor said Youth T was refusing to
follow staff directions and took off her shift. “I told her I’d have to
escort her to her room for the safety of her peers. She pulled the
fire alarm and I put her in a one-man PRT to escort to her room.
She resisted and dropped to the floor. She ended up in a
standing PRT wall restraint. She deescalated and allowed me to
escort her to her room.”
3

I asked Supervisor why he initiated a one-man PRT escort on
Youth T for pulling a fire alarm. He responded, “I didn’t start the
escort because she pulled the fire alarm. I started it because she
took her shirt off.” I asked Supervisor why Youth T taking her shirt
off is a safety issue. He stated “Youths can see out of their
windows. If a youth is exposing herself on the pod, they would be
victimized by what they’d see. Some are already victims of sex
abuse. Age also makes a difference here. Others on the pod are
under 18,” he explained. “It is a sex offense for her to expose
herself to youth. It’s reoffending. If we allowed her to victimize
other youth, we’d be negligent of the other youth,” he reasoned.
I interviewed Staff 1 who has worked at the facility as a youth
specialist for over two years. I reminded her of the incident on
7/25/23 and asked if the escort that developed into a physical
restraint of Youth T was justified. Staff 1 responded emphatically,
“Absolutely! It was justified because just a few weeks ago, she
took her clothes off and smeared menstrual blood on me. She is
a grown woman and was threatening to kick my ass. She told me
‘You thought I was bad last time...’ I called Supervisor.”
I asked more about Youth T removing her clothes. Staff 1
explained “We can’t have her exposing herself to kids. She’s 18.
We have six other youths under 17 on the pod. We need to
protect the other youths from that.” I reminded her that the other
youths were in their rooms when this happened. She said from
their rooms, they can still see out of their windows. Staff 1
summarized some of the challenges of mixing adult sex offenders
with younger traumatized youth. “We have high boundaries here
(related to dressing modesty) because of their (youths) traumas.
Youth T is in sex offender treatment and has grooming tendencies
such as giving away snacks to (younger) youths.”
I interviewed Therapist who has been a group leader at the facility
for five years. She said she has a master’s degree in Trauma
Counseling and is a certified Crisis Prevention trainer.
Therapist explained Youth T’s records from Macomb County
Detention Center show she has a history of exposing herself and
attacking staff. Since June 2023, Youth T has exposed herself
twice on the pod at Bay Pines. Therapist explained why disrobing
is a safety issue. “Taking off clothes is triggering and traumatizes
other youth. It’s a pattern where Youth T escalates into physical
aggression from there. In certain instances, I feel this (behavior)
can warrant physical restraint. I say that because it’s done to
4

minimize harm to others and preserve the youth’s own dignity.”
Therapist also mentioned the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA)
as a law requiring staff to protect youth in institutions from sexual
victimization. Additionally, she explained that the loud noises and
flashing lights from a pulled fire alarm are re-traumatizing to the
other youths and sends them into flashbacks.
Child Caring Institution Licensing Rule 400.4160 Emergency
restraint identifies restraint as a “lifesaving response…to protect
the youth or others from an unanticipated or severely aggressive
behavior that places the youth or others at serious threat of
violence or injury if no immediate intervention occurs.” Using
restraint pre-emptively to protect others from being emotionally
triggered or retraumatized are not included as justification.
Analysis Although Supervisor, who is a Handle with Care trainer, utilized
approved physical management techniques, in this case,
restraining Youth T for removing her shirt or pulling the fire alarm
was not justified. Less restrictive interventions to de-escalate her
should have been continued.
CONSULTATION
All of the staff interviewed were extremely knowledgeable of the
treatment strategies and interventions for both victims and
offenders of sexual abuse. While often offenders were once
victims, it is challenging to treat victims and offenders on the same
pod and ideally, they should be separated. In residential
treatment, it is also best practice to separate minors from adults,
but the facility has neither the space nor the resources to do so.
Given the circumstances, the staff must find new ways to protect
youths from other youths while still adhering to the current
licensing rules regarding seclusion and restraint.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established for Rule 400.4159 (2)

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
